fields.name: Tempus Fugit Kina L'Aéro d'Or QuinaQuina
Art in the Age Chicory Liqueur
Copper & Kings American Craft Aged Brandy
Licor De Granada Amargo Bitter Pomegranate
Against the Grain
fields.directions: Shake with ice, pour into a chilled coupe glass. Garnish with a lemon wedge.
fields.description: Based on "Against the Strain" from Drunk & Told, which is a gin variation of the Paper Plane.

fields.name: Deep Six / Paradiso Frankenstein
fields.directions: Muddle with lots of mint, shake with ice. Strain the drink, take the mint out of the shaker and put it in the glass.

fields.name: Garden Car
fields.directions: Shake with ice, pour into a coupe glass, garnish with a cherry.
fields.description: A sidecar variation, with floral and honey and Gran Classico in for the the triple sec.

fields.name: Not a Banana
fields.directions: Shake and strain and call it a day.

fields.name: Of Course You Know, This Means War
fields.directions: Stir with ice, pour into a frozen coupe glass. Garnish with a baby carrot and a basil sprig. Experiment with celery bitters or a pinch of salt.
fields.description: Inspired by carrot cocktails at Drink.

fields.name: Sfumato Last Word
fields.directions: Ginger liqueur can be subbed for the maraschino, which is good but slightly less complex.

fields.name: Smoke & Magic
fields.directions: Stir with ice, serve over solid ice brick in a chilled rocks glass. Armagnac or cognac are a good substitute for the Laphroaig.

fields.name: Smoked Peach
fields.directions: Combine and serve over crushed ice, slice of peach and a lime wedge in the glass. Rum optional, frankly. Made with “Just Peach”.

fields.name: Special Counsel
fields.directions: Shake with ice, pour into coupe glass. Experiment with bitters and garnish, maybe a luxardo cherry. Experiment with Campari for color.
fields.description: A variation of the Josie Packard's Prosecutor with smoky amaro and Strega.

fields.name: Swiss Summer
fields.directions: Wash the glass with Sfumato. Combine the Gran Classico and clementine, pour over crushed ice, add a squeeze of lime and garnish with the wedge. (And maybe a mint sprig.)

fields.name: The Phantom of the Grapefruit
fields.directions: Shake with ice, strain into a coupe glass. Garnish with a grapefruit peel.

fields.name: WFH Tuesday
fields.directions: Shake and serve over ice.

fields.name: Witch Hunt
fields.directions: Shake and serve on the rocks or up, with mint garnish.
fields.description: "Strega" means "witch" in Italian.  This is a handy cocktail when slowly losing your mind over the news cycle.

fields.name: Last Word
fields.directions: Shake ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled glass.
fields.description: Easy to assemble but hard to forget, this Prohibition-era Last Word cocktail has found its way into a new generation of cocktail glasses thanks in part to Seattle-based bartender Murray Stenson who helped re-popularize the drink.

fields.name: Manhattan
fields.directions: Stir with ice, pour into cocktail glass and garnish with a maraschino cherry.
fields.description: A popular history suggests that the drink originated at the Manhattan Club in New York City in the early 1870s, where it was invented by Dr. Iain Marshall for a banquet hosted by Jennie Jerome in honor of presidential candidate Samuel J. Tilden.

fields.name: The Lumière
fields.directions: Combine all ingredients in a large glass filled with ice. Stir thoroughly and strain the mixture into a coupe. Garnish with a lime twist.
fields.description: This recipe, developed by Nitehawk Cinema's Beverage Director Jen Marshall, was inspired by the Oscar-nominated film Hugo. The magical sophistication of elderflower, citrus, and green chartreuse mirrors Hugo's and Isabella's enchanting quest through 1930's Paris.

fields.name: Sazerac
fields.directions: Coat a chilled old fashioned glass in Herbsaint.  Stir the other ingredients with ice, then double strain into the glass.  Pinch a lemon twist over the drink to express oils onto its surface, then rub the twist around the glass rim to coat. Discard the twist.
fields.description: The Sazerac is an unusual old-school drink with the fine distinction of The Official Cocktail of New Orleans. No garnish, no ice, no citrus juice – but deeply refreshing and smooth. It was originally made with Cognac, but since 1880 or so, rye whiskey has been the standard. And that’s a good thing: Rye’s peppery intensity gets a serious flavor going up front where Cognac might just lay back and take it.

fields.name: Santa Rosella
fields.directions: Apply a spice mixture (paprika, sea salt, sugar) to the rim of a chilled coupe glass.  Spritz the glass with absinthe.  Shake the other ingredients with ice and strain into the glass.

fields.name: Penicillin
fields.directions: Shake up non-scotch ingredients and strain into cocktail glass. Pour a little Ardbeg on top as a "smoky floater"
fields.description: Haven't made this in a while, maybe too much sweet for current tastes?

fields.name: Red Headed Goodbye
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into glass.
fields.description: Grace's Variation of the Last Goodbye. Use real Grenadine, not the candy stuff.

fields.name: Industry Sour
fields.directions: Combine all with ice. Shake and strain into a cocktail glass.
fields.description: Green Chartreuse is kind of a mixologist's favorite, as well as Fernet. Both of those ingredients have so much intense flavor that people often shy away from them, but bartenders definitely drink them. They each have unique flavor profiles, and with sours, people in the industry really look for a challenge to a palate and intense reactions. It's comforting at first, and then all of a sudden it hits your palate with a bomb of flavor. It's sweet, it's spicy, it's intense, it's minty

fields.name: Roasted Veg
fields.directions: Shake until ice cold and serve strained. Garnish with fresh herbs or sliced veg.

fields.name: Summer and Smoke
fields.directions: Shake until cold and strain. Garnish with orange in the glass for some boozy fruit. Can add a splash of blood orange syrup or simple for someone who needs an edge off the bitter.

fields.name: Little Valiant
fields.directions: Mix all but salt until cold and pour over a large ice cube. Sprinkle salt over the ice.

fields.name: The Fig Zucca
fields.directions: Place a luxardo maraschino cherry in the center of a coupe glass. Shake ingredients over ice until cold, pour over cherry.
fields.description: First drink created after buying Black Fig Vodka at a BSFW tasting

fields.name: Andorra Sour
fields.directions: Shake the egg white with the citrus and rye, without ice.  Add the amaro and syrup and shake with ice.  Strain into a coupe glass.

fields.name: Evil Chupacabra
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a cocktail glass
fields.description: Grace's variation on the Chupacabra.

fields.name: Dumpster Fire
fields.directions: Shake well over ice and pour in a glass.
fields.description: Grace's attempt to use up the end of the lime juice (aka "trash cocktail" ) yielded this smokey beauty.

fields.name: Cravat
fields.directions: Stir with ice and strain into a rocks glass with fresh ice.
fields.description: Created by Brayden Burroughs, Esq. of Dudekicker for a Bols Genever industry event at the Franklin.

fields.name: Campari Basil Mojito
fields.directions:
In the bottom of a cocktail shaker or glass, add the brown sugar, lime juice and 1/4 cup basil leaves. Muddle together with a muddler or a spoon until the sugar has mostly dissolved into the lime juice and there is a nice basil scent released from the leaves.
Add the Campari and stir well to combine.
Fill a Collins glass or other glass with crushed ice.
Pour the Campari-basil mixture over the ice and top with a splash of sparkling water. Serve with basil leaves for garnish.
fields.description: This was the first Campari drink Grace ever liked. An amazing porch sipper.

fields.name: Savage Sunset
fields.directions: Shake over ice and strain into a cocktail glass. Play around with garnish (maybe a burnt orange peel?)
fields.description: A bitter citrusy attempt at a drink that doesn't use fresh citrus.

fields.name: Sidecar
fields.directions: In cocktail shaker, combine Cognac, Cointreau, and lemon juice. Add ice and shake vigorously until well chilled, about 30 seconds. Strain into prepared (sugar rimmed) martini or coupe glass and serve.

fields.name: Duchess of Sussex
fields.directions:
Shake over ice and pour into a coupe or cocktail glass. 
Champagne Syrup is simple syrup made with leftover flat champagne.
fields.description: This is a guess at the proportions of the cocktail made at Rules, the oldest restaurant in London, and talked up by our favorite bartender Sam as the best thing he'd drunk recently. Described as a "sidecar variation with elderflower liqueur for the Cointreau and Champagne syrup". Apparently it is the second Rules drink named for Meghan Markle.

fields.name: You Gotta Wait
fields.directions:
Wine Syrup, like Champagne Syrup, is made in a 2:1 red wine:sugar ratio.

Shake with ice and strain into a glass of choice.
fields.description: Park of Grace's experimentation with wine syrups. Captures some of the character of the red wine with a much higher proof. Name is inspired by a Mitch Hedberg joke.

fields.name: French 75
fields.directions: Combine gin, simple syrup, and lemon juice in a cocktail shaker filled with ice. Shake until well chilled and strain into a glass. Top with Champagne and garnish with a lemon twist to serve.
fields.description: Named for an innovative piece of French artillery and comprising just four ingredients — gin, lemon, simple syrup, Champagne — the French 75, when made properly, features nose-tickling bubbly as the gateway to a perfectly integrated combination of floral gin and citrus.

fields.name: The Queen's Nod
fields.directions: Shake over ice and strain into a coupe.
fields.description:
Made by experimenting with blood orange juice, off a Blood Orange Negroni recipe. Starts off sweet, with a bitter finish, and named for its "elite" ingredients and royal blood (orange).

Still a work in progress, could experiment with:
Salt
A mezcal or Scotch floater

fields.name: Unnamed #1
fields.directions: Shake over ice and strain into a cold coupe. Squeeze orange oil from a wide twist of orange peel and garnish with twist.
fields.description: Made by Jared Conklin at No. 9 Park from the request of a drink with Braulio.

fields.name: Two Quinas Walk Into a Bar
fields.directions: Stir with ice, pour into a cocktail coupe, garnish with oil from an orange twist.
fields.description: A lovely sweet rye drink. Greg put this together while inventing drinks that don't contain any citrus for his parents.  (The orange oil was a late addition.)

fields.name: French Rose
fields.directions: Shake all but wine over ice, pour into a cocktail glass and top with Rose.
fields.description: A French 75 with Rose flair.

fields.name: January Hug
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a coupe glass.
fields.description: A modification of the "Fig Manhattan" recipe off the back of the Liber & Co Caramelized Fig Syrup, makes use of the vanilla base of Old Monk and the coffee notes of Sibilia.

fields.name: Sfumato Sour
fields.directions: Shake with ice and double strain into a cocktail coupe, serve without garnish.
fields.description: A bartender's whim from Backbar in 2019 when asking for "something with Sfumato".

fields.name: End of Childcare Day
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a coupe glass.
fields.description: While technically a childcare recovery drink should contain gin, this is a no-nonsense way to take the edge off without anything weird like cinnamon syrup or Kümmel or something.

fields.name: Quina Kick It
fields.directions: Stir with ice, strain into a cocktail coupe and garnish with a lemon peel.
fields.description: A delicious half and half that is sweeter than it has any reason to be.

fields.name: Man About Town
fields.directions: Stir with ice, strain into a chilled martini glass and garnish with a brandied cherry.
fields.description: This cocktail from Gramercy Tavern in NYC is a take on a Boulevardier (which is like a Negroni, but with bourbon or rye instead of gin). Here, spicy rye is the star, complemented by the bittersweet Sicilian amaro, Cynar.

fields.name: Smoked Marasca
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a rocks glass with a large ice cube.  Garnish with three luxardo cherries on a toothpick.
fields.description: A smoky sweet cherry mezcal margarita from BarTaco in 2019.

fields.name: Negroni
fields.directions: Stir with ice, pour into a rocks glass, and garnish with an orange twist.
fields.description: Easy to make and refreshingly bitter, the Negroni is said to have been invented in Florence by a dauntless Italian count who demanded that the bartender replace the club soda in his Americano with gin. It was a substitution that launched a thousand riffs.

fields.name: Boulevardier
fields.directions: Stir with ice, pour into a cocktail coupe with a large ice cube, garnish with an orange twist.
fields.description: Swap out the gin in a Negroni for rye whiskey and you get the delicious Boulevardier. It’s equally complex as its gin-based predecessor, but the whiskey adds warmth, making it perfect for autumn and winter drinking.

fields.name: Scofflaw
fields.directions: Shake with ice, strain into a cocktail glass.
fields.description: This whiskey drink was invented in Paris while the U.S. suffered through Prohibition.

fields.name: Daiquiri
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a cocktail coupe glass.  Garnish with a lime twist.
fields.description: The Daiquiri is simple and sublime, a delicate blend of rum’s sweetness with the raw freshness of sugar and lime juice.

fields.name: Vieux Carré
fields.directions: Stir with ice, strain into a rocks glass, garnish with a lemon peel.
fields.description: The Vieux Carré was first stirred to life at New Orleans’ legendary Hotel Monteleone in the 1930s. Like so many classic cocktails from that city, the recipe represents the crosscurrents of America at the time: brandy and liqueur from France, Italian vermouth, rye whiskey from just up the Mississippi and Caribbean bitters. The Vieux Carré is at once boozy, sweet, bitter and smooth—in other words, New Orleans.

fields.name: Winter's Stake
fields.directions: Shake all vigorously with ice and strain into a cocktail glass.
fields.description: Inspired by what was around while making steak and Amaro Sours, the rosemary brings out the wintry notes of the Braulio.

fields.name: Steph's Request
fields.directions: Shake all but water over ice. Strain into a highball glass filled with ice or a rocks glass with a big ice ball. Top with soda water, garnish with some spanked mint.
fields.description: This non-alcoholic winter drink was whipped up for someone who couldn't drink alcohol but wanted to have a fancy glass.

fields.name: Margarita
fields.directions: Line the rim of a rocks glass with salt, shake with ice, and strain into the glass.  Garnish with a lime wheel.
fields.description: The Margarita is one of the most popular cocktails in North America—for good reason. Combining the tang of lime and the sweetness of orange liqueur with the distinctive strength of tequila, our classic Margarita strikes all of the right keys.

fields.name: Monkey's Cuss
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into glass over crushed ice.
fields.description: Here’s a bonus Billy Elliot drink that I threw together at our party using ingredients on hand. I had the name, so purposely brought along the creme de banana. Everything else was impromptu, but really worked in the final drink. No monkeys were harmed in the making of the cocktail, though some feelings were hurt. Those monkeys can swear.

fields.name: Show You Me Hoo-hoo
fields.directions: Shake with ice then strain into coupe.
fields.description: Final Billy Elliot drink, and my tiki contribution. The shrub and cinnamon give it a nice bite. And it is probably my favorite name I have given one of my cocktails. Though the cocktail is all you get.

fields.name: Esqueer
fields.directions: Shake with ice then strain into coupe.
fields.description: Billy Elliot drink #3. Still love the pamplemousse rose liqueur. Everything else was just invited to play with it. The title comes from a line in the show where Billy misreads “esquire.” Hold for laugh. Now drink.

fields.name: Balletomane
fields.directions: Stir with ice, then strain into old fashioned over ice. Express orange peel over drink and discard.
fields.description: Drink #2 for Billy Elliot. Submitted without witty commentary.

fields.name: For God’s Sake, Jackie!
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into coupe. Garnish with 4 drops of rose water and rose petals.
fields.description: Here’s a cocktail I did for my cast of Billy Elliot at Seacoast Repertory Theatre in Portsmouth, New Hampshire. Nothing thematic about the drink, but the title is from a line in the show (and my character’s name). I’d been sitting on both the rose liqueur and mint tea liqueur, so it was nice to utilize them. Skip the rose petals, by the way. Makes for a nice pic but detracts from the drink. I thought it would be a nice touch. I was wrong. For God’s sake, Jackie!

fields.name: NOLA Bookend
fields.directions: Stir with ice and strain over ice into old fashioned glass rinsed with absinthe.
fields.description:
I wanted to commemorate a recent trip to New Orleans with a drink inspired by my morning routine there of coffee with chicory (and beignets, but couldn’t fit that into the cocktail). Here is my take on the evening routine I could imagine closing out the ritual.

Started with a Louisiana rum and added the NOLA coffee liqueur. This already has chicory, but I bumped this up with an additional chicory liqueur. Surprisingly this isnt too sweet at this point, thus the simple syrup, and then bitters to round things out. The absinthe is present on the nose and is an obvious nod to the Sazerac.

Then just have a beignet on the side.

fields.name: Daylight Come
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain over cracked ice.
fields.description: Here is my tiki offering WITH citrus. I love love love banana liqueur. You might even catch me upping the amount here to 3/4 an ounce. Nothing wrong with that.

fields.name: Left at Albuquerque
fields.directions: Shake with ice then strain into a Nick and Nora.
fields.description: Here I had the carrot brandy and the dill aquavit and wanted to build something around those. Very vegetal and tasty.

fields.name: Scurvy Dog
fields.directions: Stir with ice and strain into coupe or over cracked ice into tiki mug.
fields.description: Don’t have much to say on this one, except I wanted a tiki cocktail that didnt require me to have fruit on hand. Nice and rummy with bright and bitter notes.

fields.name: How D’ya Like Them Apples
fields.directions: Stir with ice and strain into a coupe. Garnish with dehydrated apple slice and a spritz of absinthe.
fields.description:
This may be my first cocktail I’ve listed that is not tied to a show or challenge. But I have a lot of them written down and thought it was time to record them here. This one was all about the apple cordial and cider syrup. Combining with fennel just made sense. I will admit I repeated this one a few nights in a row.

Edit: This is much better with blood orange syrup subbed instead of fig (and probably better if you use the actual cider syrup called for. Also, I don't know if its the spritz of absinthe but it packs quite a punch tipsy-wise.

fields.name: Muddled Monk
fields.directions: In an old-fashioned glass, muddle the sweet lime chunks and pour in the rest of the ingredients. Top with crushed ice and garnish with a twist of sweet lime peel.
fields.description: One of the first cocktails, showcased at Ball Square Fine Wines, that taught Grace about different rums. The high citrus content meets the deep vanilla of the Old Monk.

fields.name: Oaxacan Old Fashioned
fields.directions:
Add all the ingredients into an Old Fashioned glass with 1 large ice cube, and stir until chilled.  Garnish with a flamed orange peel.  

To top with a flamed orange twist, carefully hold the piece of orange peel skin side down over a lit match to warm the peel.  Then holding the match a few inches above the drink, quickly squeeze the peel in the direction of the match.  The oil from the peel will briefly ignite and land on the drink.
fields.description: Nice, smokey, play on an Old Fashioned.  A new classic.

fields.name: Two Witches Walk into a Fruit Stand
fields.directions: Shake all vigorously over ice and and strain into a coupe or goblet spritzed with absinthe.
fields.description: Grace wanted to make a witch-named drink to honor the two witch named liquors (Strega and Donna Rosa), plus play with the witch implications of apples and the magical properties of wormwood. Feel free to swap in some other fruity syrup for the pomegranate.

fields.name: Sea Glass
fields.directions: Stir over ice and strain into a cold coupe glass. Garnish with lemon oil.
fields.description: This was described as a "fennel martini" by its creator, but is truly a refreshing and complex fennel creation, not an anise bomb. Fennel syrup should be homemade by crushing fennel seed into the sugar for simple.

fields.name: Mutilator
fields.directions: Stir with ice, strain into a cocktail coupe.
fields.description: Simple but light pairing of two low ABV ingredients to make a delicious cocktail.  The sherry has the dominant note here.  Named, apparently, after a political struggle with being a junior bartender with a new recipe to name.

fields.name: Flip Fantastic
fields.directions: Shake once without ice and then with ice.  Serve in a Nick & Nora glass with freshly grated nutmeg for garnish.  Add a barspoon of demerara syrup to make it more accessible to the uninitiated.
fields.description: Adding egg to Punch Fantastic feels a little like cheating.

fields.name: Jameggy Jellobee
fields.directions: Shake all without ice and then with ice. Strain (or double strain, if necessary) into a coupe. Rinse the coupe with Sfumato if you want to be daring.
fields.description: This was a challenge drink to create something by this name that had Egg and Jam. This version is a beautiful sherbet orange, but with a sour finish.

fields.name: Sardinian Iced Tea
fields.directions: Fill a Collins glass with ice. Pour Amaro in (different amaros will give different variations). Cut a thin wheel off the half lemon for garnish. Squeeze the juice from the half lemon into the drink. Top with prosecco (or champagne) to your liking. Depending on the amaro you may want to stir a bit so it doesn't all sit at the bottom. Garnish with the lemon wheel.
fields.description: Grace's introduction to Amaro! She first had the drink at Coppa in Boston and tried to reproduce, slowly discovering that Amaro was not a single liquor but a whole genre where every different Amaro is distinct. Using Lucano or Donna Rosa is great, using Cardamaro not so much. But play around. This is the perfect porch drink, simple, boozy, refreshing.

fields.name: Dirty Word
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a cocktail coupe.  Garnish with a cherry or a lime peel.
fields.description: A Last Word variation inspired by the Industry Sour and other various Fernet drinks.  This is earthy, tart, and complex.  Experiment with other fernets, preferably less minty ones.

fields.name: Ruination Day
fields.directions: Pour Cynar into a chilled glass. Add a pinch of salt. Slap a sage leaf and garnish. Listen to Time (The Revelator) and sip.
fields.description: This bittersweet drink is served warm.

fields.name: The Getaway
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a Nick & Nora glass.  Note: Simple should be rich - 3 parts sugar to 1 part water.
fields.description: Richly rounded, deepened with the higher-proof version of artichoke-based amaro Cynar, this elegant and beautifully balanced drink was an early Columbia Room original, composed on the spot for a customer who wanted a daiquiri with Cynar in it.

fields.name: Green Point
fields.directions: Stir with ice and strain into a cocktail glass.  Garnish with a cherry.
fields.description: Nicked surrepetitiously from the bartender's card catalog while sitting at the bar on a date.

fields.name: Alaska
fields.directions: Stir with ice and strain into a cocktail glass.  Garnish with a lemon twist.  Can substitute Aperol for the Yellow Chartreuse.
fields.description: Nicked surrepetitiously from the bartender's card catalog while sitting at the bar on a date.

fields.name: Blinker
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a cocktail glass.  Garnish with lemon oil from a twist.
fields.description: Nicked surrepetitiously from the bartender's card catalog while sitting at the bar on a date.

fields.name: Blackball
fields.directions: Stir with ice, strain into a rocks glass with a large ice cube.
fields.description: A tasty Manhattan variation.  Vary up the amaro to keep it interesting.

fields.name: Table Flip
fields.directions: Shake without ice and then with ice.  Double strain into a coupe glass, and garnish with a light dusting of red chili powder.  Substitute Sfumato Amaro for the Cyclist.
fields.description: A challenge recipe to "make something with Cyclist and Velvet Falernum", and named after a bad day with hot dogs.

fields.name: Veruca Salt
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a cocktail glass with a salt rim.  Garnish with lemon oil from a twist.
fields.description: A complex margarita-like concoction that goes great with BBQ at the start of summer.

fields.name: Easy Peasy
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a cocktail coupe.  Garnish with two cherries.
fields.description: A variation of a Debonair, this is an attempt to build an interesting cocktail with few ingredients while keeping things simple, easy, and delicious.

fields.name: Tom Collins
fields.directions: Pour the gin, lemon juice and simple syrup into an ice filled collins glass. Top with club soda and stir gently. Garnish with a lemon slice and cherry.
fields.description: The epitome of 1950's suburbia, this classic drink was actually created in the mid-1800's by John Collins, barman at Limmer's Hotel in London, as a variation on his Holland gin-based John Collins cocktail. The original drink was named after the slightly sweet Old Tom gin, as opposed to the the later version made with London dry gin, which became much more popular, catching on here after World War I vets brought it back home to America.

fields.name: Springtime for Hitler
fields.directions: Go scant on the Kümmel unless feeling particularly adventurous.  Shake with ice, strain into a cocktail coupe, and garnish with parsley dipped in salt water.
fields.description: A challenge drink to use Kümmel and Thyme liqueur concocted at the first Drinksperimentation night at Redwood Street.

fields.name: Barrington
fields.directions: Stir with ice, strain into a rocks glass with a large ice cube, and garnish with a lemon peel.
fields.description: An iced-espresso take on an Old Fashioned.  This is an excellent brunch cocktail if you’re looking for coffee instead of mimosas.

fields.name: King of Iron, King of Bricks
fields.directions: Stir over ice and strain into an absinthe-spritzed glass. Squeeze lemon oil from a peel over the top and rub around the rim of the glasss. Add a Copper and Kings Brandied Cherry if desired.
fields.description: The "Hades" cocktail from Grace's 2019 Tony's themed cocktails. Bitter, smoky, dark, with hidden flowers.

fields.name: City of Dis
fields.directions: Stir with ice, strain into rocks glass, and garnish with oil from a lemon peel.  Substitute Sfumato for the Cyclist Amaro, or Rye for the Japanese Whisky.
fields.description: An equal parts dark variation of a Toronto, made as a suggestion for the "Hades" drink on Grace's 2019 Tony Awards cocktail menu.

fields.name: Everyday Superhero
fields.directions: Muddle 2 blackberries in a large rocks glass. Combine all other ingredients in a shaker tin. Shake vigorously for 10 seconds. Strain over fresh ice in a large rocks glass. Garnish with two blackberries.

fields.name: Mojito
fields.directions:
Lightly muddle the mint in a shaker.
Add the rum, lime juice, simple syrup and ice and give it a brief shake.
Strain into a highball glass.
Top with the club soda.
Garnish with a mint sprig

fields.name: Cucumber Gin Gimlet
fields.directions: In a shaker, muddle the cucumber and simple syrup. Add the gin and lime juice, then fill with ice and shake vigorously. Fine-strain the liquid into a chilled coupe or martini glass, garnish with a sliver of cucumber and serve.

fields.name: Undefeated Since 1861
fields.directions: Shake all with ice, strain into a cocktail glass. Squeeze a lemon peel over the top and rub the oil on the rim. Garnish with lemon peel and mint. Best while listening to Paul Simon's Graceland.
fields.description: Made during Vassar reunion 2019.

fields.name: 2⁶
fields.directions: Stir with ice and strain into a rocks glass.  Garnish with a lemon peel.
fields.description: A variation on Hungry Mother's #64, this one is open to variation both on the scotch and the sweet vermouth.

fields.name: Better Monk
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a cocktail coupe.
fields.description: A variation of the Tom Schlesinger-Guidelli's Bitter Monk, because why would anyone use aperol. A tasty, easy to make tiki.

fields.name: Bathtub Armada
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a coupe or tiki (add ice if you want it a little less intense). Garnish with spanked mint sprigs and fresh grated nutmeg.
fields.description: Grace's favorite riff on Adriatic Yacht Club, Brandon Rucker's Italian riff on the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club.

fields.name: Not A Negroni
fields.directions: Stir with ice and strain into a rocks glass.  Garnish with a wide orange twist.
fields.description: Created for the second Drinksperimentation night, this Negroni variation has all the look and feel of a classic Negroni but is ultimately very different.

fields.name: Frosty AF
fields.directions: Blend all ingredients with at least 5 ice cubes until smooth and frosty. Garnish with Tiki Bitters or whatever fruit you like.
fields.description: A tasty, strong cold drink in a tropical vein for 90 degree days.

fields.name: Vesper
fields.directions:
Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir (or, if preparing the Bond way, shake).

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Twist a slice of lemon peel over the drink, rub along the rim of the glass, and drop it in.
fields.description:
The Vesper, also known as the Vesper Martini, was made famous by James Bond. The cocktail best known for being ordered “shaken not stirred” was invented by none other than Bond author Ian Fleming. The Vesper first appeared in his book “Casino Royale,” which was published in 1953 and gets its name from fictional double agent Vesper Lynd.

When Bond orders the Vesper, it comes with strict instructions that must be followed by any who make it: “Three measures of Gordon’s, one of vodka, half a measure of Kina Lillet. Shake it very well until it’s ice-cold, then add a large thin slice of lemon peel. Got it?”

With respect to 007, shaking a Vesper can result in an overly diluted drink. The golden rule is to always stir a spirit-only drink. And we see no reason to change that here.

fields.name: Aviation
fields.directions:
Add all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.

Strain into a cocktail glass.

Garnish with a brandied cherry.
fields.description: A classic gin sipper dating back to the turn of the 20th century, the Aviation was all but forgotten until about a decade ago. That’s when its secret-weapon ingredient, crème de violette, reappeared on the American market. Today, the cocktail is distinguished by its purple-bluish hue and floral, citrus flavors. And to that, everyone say, welcome back!

fields.name: Paloma
fields.directions:
Add the tequila and lime juice to a highball glass filled with ice.

Fill with grapefruit soda to top, and stir briefly.

fields.name: Dot Cocktail
fields.directions: Stir with ice, strain into a rocks glass, and garnish with a lemon twist.
fields.description: An update to the Aperol-heavy "Todd Cocktail", with a spin on the name to pay homage to Dorchester where it was created.

fields.name: Basil Gimlet
fields.directions: Put basil leaves in a cocktail shaker and press them gently with a muddler or a wooden spoon. Add the gin, lime juice and simple syrup. Fill with ice, shake vigorously and strain into a chilled coupe or other small glass. Garnish with a basil leaf.
fields.description: A summer garden gimlet from the New York Times.

fields.name: Stinger
fields.directions: Shake with ice, strain into a cocktail glass.
fields.description: "Stingers, and keep them coming." — Cary Grant, as a navy pilot, in "Kiss Them for Me".

fields.name: The Jimbo
fields.directions: Pour the Meletti into a shot glass and float the rye on top.  Take as a shot.
fields.description: Invented by Jimmy Palumbo at Extra Fancy in Brooklyn.

fields.name: Peony
fields.directions: Shake over ice and pour into a coupe. Garnish with a spritz of oil from a grapefruit peel for something special.
fields.description: A self-challenge to create a pink floral drink inspired by a vase of peonies, this drink is a gorgeous fuchsia color and pleasantly sweet and floral. If you don't have the candied hibiscus flower syrup maybe some fresh grenadine or simple with a few drops of Peychaud's.

fields.name: Fig Manhattan
fields.directions: Stir all in a mixing glass with ice. Strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a maraschino cherry.
Stir with ice, strain into a cocktail glass, and garnish with an orange peel.
fields.description: A classic cocktail that combines the Boulevardier with the Manhattan.

fields.name: Japanese Cocktail
fields.directions: Stir with ice, strain into a cocktail glass, garnish with a lemon peel.
fields.description: A classic from the 1864 "How to Mix Drinks" by Jerry Thomas.

fields.name: Ab Fab
fields.directions: Shake with ice, strain into a martini glass.
fields.description: What a Cosmopolitan hopes to be when it grows up.

fields.name: Havana Cocktail
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a cocktail glass.
fields.description: A very sweet standard, optionally garnished with a lemon twist.

fields.name: Rome With a View
fields.directions: Shake with ice (except soda water), strain into a Collins glass containing 2 oz soda water, and garnish with an orange wheel.
fields.description: Michael McIlroy invented this cross between an Americano and a Collins for a low-alcohol summer sipper.

fields.name: Seventh Heaven
fields.directions: Shake with ice, strain into a cocktail coupe, and garnish with a sprig of mint.
fields.description: A lovely gin-based classic cocktail.  Fresh-squeezed grapefruit is recommended here.

fields.name: Sensation
fields.directions: Shake with ice and double-strain into a cocktail coupe.  Garnish with a sprig of mint.
fields.description: A gin-based classic featuring lemon and mint.

fields.name: Old Fashioned Summer
fields.directions: Stir all with ice and serve in an old fashioned glass, with a giant ice ball. Garnish with oil from an orange peel.
fields.description: An Old Fashioned by request to replicate the spiciness of the Genius recipe Old Fashioned by Using Ancho Reyes Green Chile Liqueur.

fields.name: Dead of Summer
fields.directions: Shake over ice and serve in a cold glass.
fields.description: Grace's attempt to riff on Palace of the Dead. Go scant on the passion fruit, it can overpower.

fields.name: Flying American
fields.directions: Shake over ice and strain in a cocktail glass.
fields.description: A paper plane variation using St. George's sophisticated Campari alternative.

fields.name: The Other One
fields.directions: Stir over ice and strain into a cocktail glass. Play with a lemon garnish.
fields.description: A bartender's whim using the tricky Erborista.

fields.name: Lion's Tail
fields.directions: Shake with ice, strain into a cocktail glass, and garnish with a lime twist.
fields.description: First published in the Café Royal Cocktail Book in 1937, this cocktail originally called for gomme syrup instead of simple.

fields.name: Singapore Sling
fields.directions: Shake with ice (except soda water), strain into a Collins glass, fill with ice and top with 2 oz soda water.  Garnish with a lemon twist and a cherry.
fields.description: A classic cocktail, originally developed by Ngiam Tong Boon at the Raffles Hotel in Singapore circa 1915.  Feel free to vary the quantities or experiment with grenadine or pineapple juice.

fields.name: Mountainista
fields.directions: Stir with ice and strain into a rocks glass with a giant ice cube. Garnish the oil from a generous strip of grapefruit peel.
fields.description: Based off the request for an amaro drink, proportions may not be correct.

fields.name: Remember the Alimony
fields.directions: Stir, serve over a giant ice cube in a rocks glass with citrus oil.
fields.description: Observed at Attaboy. Proportions may not be correct.

fields.name: Fearless & Loveless
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a coupe glass. Garnish with lemon oil from a wide peel.
fields.description: A variation on the "Love & Fear" from West Bridge.

fields.name: Bicyclette
fields.directions: Shake all but wine, strain into champagne flute, add cava and top as necessary.

fields.name: Out of the Rain
fields.directions: Stir with ice, strain into a rocks glass, garnish with a cucumber slice.  The basil simple syrup is a rich 2:1 sugar to water with a handful of basil leaves muddled into it.
fields.description: Made at a Drinksperimentation Night in response to a request for "something savory".

fields.name: Tony and Cholula
fields.directions: Slice the Jalapeño and muddle at the bottom of the mixer. Add rest of the ingredients, shake vigorously with ice and double strain into a couple glass rimmed with Tony's Creole Seasonings.
fields.description: Made at drinksperimentation off a request for the "smokiest, spiciest drink you can make - but it still has to be good". Leave out the jalapeño and/or Cholula for the less aggressive.

fields.name: Green Dream #1
fields.directions: Put basil and simple in shaker and muddle intensely until leaves are soaked with simple and giving off fresh aroma. Add rest of ingredients, add ice, and shake at least 10-12 seconds. Strain into a glass.
fields.description: Floral, fresh, spicy, yum.

fields.name: American Werewolf
fields.directions: Stir all ingredients with ice to chill, then strain into a rocks glass and serve over ice. Garnish with fresh rosemary.
fields.description: An herbaceous Negroni variation.

fields.name: Grace Under Fire
fields.directions: Shake vigorously with ice and strain into a cocktail glass. Garnish with oil from an orange peel and drop the peel in.

fields.name: August Garden
fields.directions: Shake with ice, strain into a rocks glass.  Fill with crushed ice, garnish with a Luxardo cherry, a basil leaf, and two lines of syrup from the cherry jar.
fields.description: Good for sitting in the shade after a long morning at the community garden.

fields.name: Cynar Sour
fields.directions: Shake all vigorously with ice and strain into a coupe. Garnish with a few drops of Sfumato on top.
fields.description: An amazing drink in a night of amazing drinks at Vena's Fizz House in Portland, ME. This was a drink special made by a bartender whose name I didn't catch, sadly. The saffron simple tasted on its own is very sweet - could sub a simple/strega mix. The drops of Sfumato on top add an amazing smokey aroma, and should be used in future drinks.

fields.name: Olive Oil Gimlet
fields.directions: Shake with ice, strain into a coupe glass.
fields.description: Invented at Dx5, looking for a more savory basil gin gimlet.

fields.name: Jalapeno Homebrew
fields.directions: Stir with ice (except ale) and strain into a beer glass containing the Fat Tire Amber Ale.
fields.description:
This beer cocktail perfectly recreates the jalapeño homebrew that I used to make before I had kids. It's funky and spicy and beer-y.

You can substitute any middle-of-the-road amber ale for the Fat Tire.

fields.name: Marconi Wireless
fields.directions: Stir with ice and strain into a cocktail glass. Garnish with a lemon peel.
fields.description: An Applejack based Manhattan variation whose name comes from Guglielmo Marconi, an inventor known for his pioneering work on long-distance radio transmission.

fields.name: Poor Impulse Control
fields.directions: Make chocolate sauce by melting chocolate into whole milk or heavy cream. Stir with ice and double strain into a coupe glass. Garnish with a brandied cherry.
fields.description: Made as a nightcap for my dad.

fields.name: Old North Church
fields.directions: Stir with ice, strain into a rocks glass with or without a large ice cube, garnish with a brandied cherry on a pick.
fields.description: A Negroni variation inspired by the portmanteau "Sfugroni". This recipe really lets the vermouth shine with woody undertones from the Sfumato and the juniper-y gin.

fields.name: Early October
fields.directions: Shake over ice and serve in a roly poly or glass of choice.
fields.description: An easy, equal parts, autumnal cocktail that isn't too heavy.

fields.name: Jacket Weather
fields.directions: Stir with ice and strain into a rocks glass. Garnish with an apple slice.
fields.description: A good way to start the autumn.

fields.name: Like a Fish
fields.directions: Shake all but water with a bunch of ice. Pour into your tiki mug and fill with more ice. Top with water to taste - can use flavored sparkling as well (you may use much more or less water than 6 oz). Fill the mouth of the mug with all sorts of garnish - mint, cherries, fruit.
fields.description: Part of a kick to make use of tiki glasses in non-alcoholic settings.

fields.name: Brand Ambassador
fields.directions: Shake all vigorously with ice, then strain into a coupe. If you have Bitter Axel bitters from Vena's Fizz house, drop a dash on top. Express the oil from a wide grapefruit peel on the drink and along the rim. Really, don't skip the grapefruit.
fields.description: This doesn't stray too far from the Zucca-Vanilla path others have forged, but damn is it tasty.

fields.name: Coast in the Morning
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a rocks glass, fill with crushed ice and garnish with a blackberry lime flag.
fields.description:
Experimenting with combining the funky notes of cachaça with creme de cassis. Note to future self: try out some soda water here to as a spritz.

Props to Q-Tip for the name.

fields.name: Boulevard of Blood
fields.directions:
Stir with ice, strain into a cocktail coupe, garnish with a floating clementine half.

Strained orange juice works in a pinch.
fields.description: A Halloween riff on a Boulevardier.

fields.name: Rosemary's Beach Ball
fields.directions: Shake with ice, strain into a highball glass, fill with ice, garnish with a flamed rosemary sprig dipped in Green Chartreuse.
fields.description: Made at DxEastie at the request to use some Creme de Banane.

fields.name: Simjang Sling
fields.directions: They served theirs over crushed ice in a tall glass. I served mine up with a Luxardo Cherry garnish.
fields.description: A signature drink from Simjang in Worcester, inspired by Hunter S Thompson drinking mezcal and a Singapore Sling at the same time.

fields.name: Chipper in Winter
fields.directions: Shake vigorously with ice and strain into a coupe.
fields.description: Grace's variation on a Sahil Mehta's Chipileno, swapping mezcal for tequila and angostura for the dreaded cinnamon syrup. Somehow the intensity of the angostura and the passion fruit help balance each other for a delicious tropical winter drink.

fields.name: Santa's Little Helper
fields.directions: Shake vigorously with ice and pour into a salt rimmed glass.
fields.description: Grace's Italian Greyhound variation, born out of necessity when the liquor store was out of Punt e Mes.

fields.name: Joel's Last Day
fields.directions: Toss a couple blackberries into the shaker if you have them. Shake with ice, strain into a coupe, garnish with a lime wedge.
fields.description: An off-the-cuff creation on the last night of a Joel visit, made in part to ensure he was working two drinks at once.

fields.name: Jet Ball
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a cocktail glass.
fields.description: A variation of the Bocce Ball that isn't so damn sweet.

fields.name: Bee's Knees
fields.directions: Shake with ice, strain into a coupe glass, garnish with a lemon twist.
fields.description: A classic honey recipe. Insert your favorite "buzzworthy" joke here.

fields.name: Remember the Maine
fields.directions: Stir with ice, strain into a cocktail glass, and garnish with a brandied cherry.
fields.description: A cherry infused Manhattan.

fields.name: Everyday Sadist
fields.directions: Stir with ice, strain into a coupe, and garnish with oil from a wide orange peel.

fields.name: Oak and Rowan Rum
fields.directions: Combine in shaker and strain into a coupe. Garnish with black walnut bitters
fields.description: Delicious rum drink.

fields.name: Grace's Spoke
fields.directions: Stir and strain into a Nick and Nora
fields.description: Damn good

fields.name: Yellow Word
fields.directions: Shake with ice and strain into a cocktail coupe.
fields.description: Robby Marsh at Loyal Nine invented this Last Word variation and generously shared it to cap off a bar crawl through Cambridge in the winter of 2020.

fields.name: Make It Stick
fields.directions: Shake over ice and strain into a coupe. Garnish with grapefruit oil from a wide peel.
fields.description: "How have we never combined Angostura and Sfumato before?" asks Grace incredulously, having seen the combination in the Broken Arrow at Sarma. Taking those ingredients as inspiration, leaving out any additional sweetener, she made her own dark and tasty variation.

fields.name: Yes Pecan
fields.directions: Take a small handful of toasted pecans and muddle them at the bottom of the shaker. It's ok if they are extra toasty (almost burned). Add the rest of the ingredients, shake with ice and double strain into a coupe. Triple strain if you are picky about residue in your drink.
fields.description: Grace had some extra toasty pecans and wanted to make a drink, with fantastic results.

fields.name: Bitter Days
fields.directions: Shake all together with vigor and ice and strain into a rocks glass filled with ice. Garnish with pineapple or whatever you have on hand.
fields.description: A deeply boozy, bitter forward, barely sweet tiki drink that will kick start your evening after a long day of quarantine.

fields.name: Clear Skies in Scotland
fields.directions: Shake over ice until clear and painfully cold. Strain into a coupe.
fields.description: A lightly sweet, tasty way to use the sometimes cloying Edinburgh liqueur.

fields.name: May It Stick
fields.directions: Shake all vigorously with ice and strain into a cold cocktail glass. Garnish with grapefruit oil or something else you feel like.
fields.description: Another variation of the Make It Stick, swapping the vermouth and Sfumato proportions.

fields.name: Let the Great World Spin
fields.directions: Shake all with ice and serve over ice in an old fashioned glass. Make a bamboo skewer filled with strawberries, pineapples and luxardo cherries and place it across the drink like a tightrope walker's line.
fields.description: A delicious tiki. The skewer doesn't have to be served as such but fills your nose with the smells of summer as you drink. Eventually it should be tipped into the drink for boozy fruit.

fields.name: Winking Face
fields.directions: Shake all vigorously over ice and pour into a chilled coupe. Garnish with lime oil or some bitters as you like. Go scant on the passion fruit, especially if your grapefruit juice is ripe and sweet.
fields.description: A tasty light tiki drink in a gin drink style, so named because hiding overproof rum in a light campari drink is just cheeky.
